Pre-Game Insights: Oscar Villegas is tasked with leading Bolivia to their third World Cup and their first finals appearance since the 1994 tournament in the USA.
Venezuela are looking to create history by qualifying for their first-ever World Cup finals.
Fernando Batista will be encouraged by his side's start to the qualifying campaign after seeing his side bounce back from a defeat against Colombia to take points from their next five qualifiers.
Bolivia have made an underwhelming start to their campaign, with their six qualifiers producing one win against Peru and five defeats against Brazil, Argentina, Ecuador, Paraguay and Uruguay.
Venezuela recorded home wins against Paraguay and Chile on either side of an away draw against Brazil, before they drew their last two qualifiers against Ecuador and Peru in November 2023.
Bolivia are languishing in ninth place with three points to their name, while Venezuela are in fourth position after taking nine points from six matches.
Venezuela are still waiting to end their 12-game winless away run in World Cup qualifying.
Bolivia have lost five of their six qualifiers, and will be targeting maximum points against a nation that has lost five of their six qualifiers.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Estadio Municipal El Alto is the venue for the match.
Bolivia will be without Antonio Carlos Zago, who was sacked after their poor performance at the Copa America.
Venezuela are unable to call upon Jhon Chancellor and Yangel Herrera after the pair pulled out of the squad due to injury.
Luis Haquin is expected to wear the captain's armband for Bolivia, with Carmelo Algaranaz set to lead the line.
Rondon netted three goals in four matches to finish as the second-highest scorer at the Copa America, and will attempt to continue that form when he leads the line against Bolivia.
Boris Cespedes, who plays his club football in the Swiss Super League, is likely to feature in central midfield alongside LDU Quito's Gabriel Vilamil for Bolivia.
Nahuel Ferraresi is set to operate in a centre-back pairing with Yordan Osorio for Venezuela, while Jon Aramburu and Miguel Navarro are poised to feature as the two full-backs.
The possible starting lineups for both teams have been named.
Bolivia possible starting lineup: Viscarra; Cuellar, Haquin, Sagredo; Rocha, Cespedes, Villamil, Fernandez; Miguelito, Vaca; Algaranaz
Venezuela possible starting lineup: Romo; Aramburu, Ferraresi, Osorio, Navarro; Rincon, Martinez; Bello, Segovia, Machis; Rondon
Others: The match is scheduled to take place on September 5, 2024 at 9pm UK at Estadio Municipal El Alto.
The match preview and prediction are provided by Ben Sully.
The match is part of the World Cup Qualifying - South America 2026 competition.
